title: Memory Mechanisms in Man and Machine
descriptions: The "Memory Mechanisms in Man and Machine" project aims to validate a set of 10 provocative claims related to long-term memory formation and maintenance. The project will investigate phenomena such as the recognition of visual and auditory stimuli not experienced for decades, the role of attention-related brain activity in memory storage, and the creation of "Grandmother Cells" in the neocortex. By utilizing a highly interdisciplinary approach involving psychology, neuroscience, computational modeling, and hardware development, the research team will conduct experiments using fMRI imaging, EEG recording, and intracerebral recording from epileptic patients. Additionally, computer simulations will be used to model networks of spiking neurons with Spike-Time Dependent Plasticity, and bio-inspired hardware will be developed to mimic brain memory systems. The ultimate goal of the project is to explore the parallels between human neural processes and potential artificial computing architectures, shedding light on the mechanisms underlying very long-term sensory memories. Through this research, the project aims to contribute to our understanding of memory mechanisms in both biological and artificial systems, with the potential to inform future developments in memory storage technologies.

The proposed project, "Memory Mechanisms in Man and Machine," aims to validate a set of 10 provocative claims related to long-term memory formation and maintenance. These claims include assertions such as humans being able to recognize visual and auditory stimuli not experienced for decades, the possibility of recognition without reactivating memory traces, and the role of attention-related brain activity in memory storage. The project will draw on expertise from the fields of psychology, neuroscience, computational modeling, and hardware development to explore the formation and maintenance of very long-term sensory memories.

The approach will be highly interdisciplinary, involving experimental paradigms such as fMRI imaging, EEG recording, and intracerebral recording from epileptic patients. Computer simulations using networks of spiking neurons with Spike-Time Dependent Plasticity will be used to investigate the creation of "Grandmother Cells" and the role of binary synaptic weights in memory selectivity. Additionally, bio-inspired hardware development will aim to mimic brain memory systems using memristor-like devices in artificial systems.

Overall, this project will shed light on the parallels between human neural processes and potential artificial computing architectures, with implications for understanding memory mechanisms in both biological and artificial systems.
